By using the Smart Air app, you agree to the following terms:


Smart Air is intended to provide general health and wellness guidance only. It does not constitute medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. You should always consult a qualified healthcare professional for any medical concerns.


The app may collect and store certain personal information, including your health-related data, usage patterns, and account information, to improve functionality and provide a personalized experience. Smart Air will handle your data according to applicable privacy laws and industry standards, but you acknowledge and accept the inherent risks of data storage and transmission.


While we strive to ensure the accuracy of the guidance provided, Smart Air makes no warranties or guarantees regarding the outcomes, reliability, or completeness of the information.


By using this app, you agree that Smart Air, its developers, affiliates, and partners are not liable for any loss, injury, or damages resulting from your use of the app, including reliance on its guidance or any action taken based on the information provided.


Use of the app constitutes your acknowledgment and acceptance of these terms.
Welcome to Smart Air, your centralized hub for communication regarding asthma
Controller inhalers are meant for daily use in order to control and prevent symptoms, a Rescue inhaler is meant for emergency use during an asthma attack for immediate relief
Pictured above is the privacy defaults upon creation of a Smart Air account, they can be altered by heading to \" \"
You can invite a provider to view your child\'s data by pressing the \" \" button and sharing the generated link with your provider
This is guidance, not a diagnosis. If in doubt, call emergency. Use a peak flow meter to measure your peak expiratory flow (PEF) and input it below.
This is guidance, not a diagnosis. If in doubt, call emergency. Are you experiencing any of the below symptoms? If so, fill them in and continue.
This is guidance, not a diagnosis. If in doubt, call emergency. If the flags/symptoms are critical, dial the emergency number, otherwise, continue.
This is guidance, not a diagnosis. If in doubt, call emergency. Continue by pressing the bottom right arrow button to submit your triage report.
Follow these steps to learn how to properly use an inhaler.
First, shake the inhaler for 10-15 seconds. Then, stand up straight, take a deep breath in, and exhale all the air out of your lungs

Put the inhaler in your mouth and close your lips tightly around it to make a seal. As you start to breathe in slowly and deeply, press down on the top of the inhaler one time. Keep breathing in until your lungs are full.
Remove the inhaler and hold your breath for a slow count to 10. This gives the medicine time to settle in your lungs. Afterwards, you can breathe out slowly.
